The Chapter on Akitti
The Perfection of Generosity
The Story of Mahāsudassana🔽“When I was the lord of the earth
in the city of Kusāvatī,
I was known as Mahāsudassana,
a powerful wheel-turning monarch.
There, three times a day,
I had this proclaimed here and there:
‘Who wants what? Who is in need?

original: kassa kiṁ dīyatū dhanaṁ.🔽Ko chātako ko tasito,
analyzed: kassa kim dīyatū  kaḥ chātako kaḥ tasito
translated: To whom should wealth be given?🔽Who is thirsty? Who is hungry?
Who wants garlands and ointments?
Various kinds of clothes,
who is naked and will put them on?
Who wants an umbrella on the road,
or soft and beautiful sandals?’
Thus in the evening and in the morning,

original: ghosāpemi tahiṁ tahiṁ.🔽Na taṁ dasasu ṭhānesu,🔽napi ṭhānasatesu vā;
analyzed: tahim tahi  na tam dasasu ṭhānesu  napi ṭhāna satesu vā
translated: I had this proclaimed here and there.🔽Not in ten places,🔽nor in a hundred places,
but in many hundreds of places,
was wealth given to beggars.
Whether by day or by night,
if a merchant came,
having received as much wealth as he wanted,
he left with his hands full.
Such great generosity🔽I gave for as long as I lived.
I did not give wealth out of fear,
nor was there any hoarding on my part.
Just as a sick man,
in order to be cured of his sickness,
after paying the doctor with his wealth,
is cured of his sickness.

analyzed: tathā iva aham jānamānaḥ  paripūretum asesataḥ
translated: So also, knowing that,🔽in order to fulfill it completely,
to fill up what is lacking,
I give gifts to the merchants;
without attachment, without expectation,
in order to attain full enlightenment.”
The Story of Mahāsudassana, the Fourth.
